The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on purpose and accidentally). In some cases the invaders are causing drastic changes and damage to their new habitats (e.g.: zebra mussels and the emerald ash borer in the Great Lakes region and the lion fish along the North American Atlantic coast). Some evidence suggests that invasive species are competitive in their new habitats because they are subject to less pathogen disturbance. Others report confounding evidence that occasionally suggest that species-rich communities harbor many native and exotic species simultaneously while some say that diverse ecosystems are more resilient and resist invasive plants and animals. An important question is, "do invasive species cause extinctions?" Many studies cite effects of invasive species on natives, but not extinctions. In the spring of 1800, Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula when Napoleon was still in Egypt.[note 5] After a difficult crossing over the Alps, the French army entered the plains of Northern Italy virtually unopposed. While one French army approached from the north, the Austrians were busy with another stationed in Genoa, which was besieged by a substantial force. The fierce resistance of this French army, under André Masséna, gave the northern striking force precious time to carry out their operations with little interference. After spending several days looking for each other, the two armies finally collided at the Battle of Marengo on June 14. General Melas had a numerical advantage, fielding about 30,000 Austrian soldiers while Napoleon commanded 24,000 French troops. The battle began favorably for the Austrians as their initial attack surprised the French and gradually drove them back. Melas concluded that he'd won

The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind, was Bernard de Fontenelle's Conversations on the Plurality of Worlds (1686). The book was produced specifically for women with an interest in scientific writing and inspired a variety of similar works. These popular works were written in a discursive style, which was laid out much more clearly for the reader than the complicated articles, treatises, and books published by the academies and scientists. Charles Leadbetter's Astronomy (1727) was advertised as "a Work entirely New" that would include "short and easie [sic] Rules and Astronomical Tables." The first French introduction to Newtonianism and the Principia was Eléments de la philosophie de Newton, published by Voltaire in 1738. Initially, the group was called "bums" because it referred to a group of fans who were at most games, and since those games were all day games, it was assumed they did not work. Many of those fans were, and are still, students at Chicago area colleges, such as DePaul University, Loyola, Northwestern University, and Illinois-Chicago. The group was started in 1967 by dedicated fans Ron Grousl, Tom Nall and "mad bugler" Mike Murphy, who was a sports radio host during mid days on Chicago-based WSCR AM 670 "The Score". Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current through a plough (U.S. "plow") accessed through a narrow slot in the road. In the United States, much (though not all) of the former streetcar system in Washington, D.C. (discontinued in 1962) was operated in this manner to avoid the unsightly wires and poles associated with electric traction. The same was true with Manhattan's former streetcar system. The evidence of this mode of running can still be seen on the track down the slope on the northern access to the abandoned Kingsway Tramway Subway in central London, United Kingdom, where the slot between the running rails is clearly visible, and on P and Q Streets west of Wisconsin Avenue in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington DC, where the abandoned tracks have not been paved over. In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the similarity of name, there is no documentary evidence that Edison's phonograph was based on Scott's phonautograph. Edison first tried recording sound on a wax-impregnated paper tape, with the idea of creating a "telephone repeater" analogous to the telegraph repeater he had been working on. Although the visible results made him confident that sound could be physically recorded and reproduced, his notes do not indicate that he actually reproduced sound before his first experiment in which he used tinfoil as a recording medium several months later. The tinfoil was wrapped around a grooved metal cylinder and a sound-vibrated stylus indented the tinfoil while the cylinder was rotated. The recording could be played back immediately. Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e.

In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. Napoleon sent an expedition under General Leclerc designed to reassert control over Sainte-Domingue.

Microsoft's philosophy is to provide customers with the best experience first, and allow them to make decisions themselves." Microsoft's certification guidelines for Windows 8 ultimately revealed that vendors would be required to provide means for users to re-configure or disable secure boot in their device's UEFI firmware. In the months after the Shenyang conference Peng Dehuai went to Beijing several times to brief Mao and Zhou about the heavy casualties suffered by Chinese troops and the increasing difficulty of keeping the front lines supplied with basic necessities. Peng was convinced that the war would be protracted, and that neither side would be able to achieve victory in the near future. On 24 February 1952, the Military Commission, presided over by Zhou, discussed the PVA's logistical problems with members of various government agencies involved in the war effort. After the government representatives emphasized their inability to meet the demands of the war, Peng, in an angry outburst, shouted: "You have this and that problem... You should go to the front and see with your own eyes what food and clothing the soldiers have! Not to speak of the casualties! For what are they giving their lives? We have no aircraft. We have only a few guns.

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. When the island was discovered, it was covered with unique indigenous vegetation, including a remarkable cabbage tree species. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. The sides of the field are marked by white sidelines, the goal line is marked in white, and white lines are drawn laterally across the field every 5 yards (4.6 m) from the goal line. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Clashes with the student body started on March 17, when students, aware of the anti-Catholic animosity, blocked the Klansmen from descending from their trains in the South Bend station and ripped the KKK clothes

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the antennae of male moths can detect the pheromones of female moths over distances of many kilometers. The yellow paper wasp (Polistes versicolor) is known for its wagging movements as a form of communication within the colony; it can waggle with a frequency of 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). These wagging movements can signal the arrival of new material into the nest and aggression between workers can be used to stimulate others to increase foraging expeditions. There is a pronounced tendency for there to be a trade-off between visual acuity and chemical or tactile acuity, such that most insects with well-developed eyes have reduced or simple antennae, and vice versa. There are a variety of different mechanisms by which insects perceive sound, while the patterns are not universal, insects can generally hear sound if they can produce it. Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem. The area of its jurisdiction is the entire State. A ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every court, other than the Supreme Court itself. The Israeli supreme court is both an appellate court and the high court of justice. As an appellate court, the Supreme Court considers cases on appeal (both criminal and civil) on judgments and other decisions of the District Courts. It also considers appeals on judicial and quasi-judicial decisions of various kinds, such as matters relating to the legality of Knesset elections and disciplinary rulings of the Bar Association. Romantic relationships tend to increase in prevalence throughout adolescence. By age 15, 53% of adolescents have had a romantic relationship that lasted at least one month over the course of the previous 18 months. In a 2008 study conducted by YouGov for Channel 4, 20% of 14−17-year-olds surveyed revealed that they had their first sexual experience at 13 or under in the United Kingdom. A 2002 American study found that those aged 15–44 reported that the average age of first sexual intercourse was 17.0 for males and 17.3 for females. The typical duration of relationships increases throughout the teenage years as well. This constant increase in the likelihood of a long-term relationship can be explained by sexual maturation and the development of cognitive skills necessary to maintain a romantic bond (e.g. caregiving, appropriate attachment), although these skills are not strongly developed until late adolescence. Long-term relationships allow adolescents to gain the skills necessary for high-quality relationships later in life

A predator's effect on its prey species is hard to see in the short-term. However, if observed over a longer period of time, it is seen that the population of a predator will correlationally rise and fall with the population of its prey in a cycle similar to the boom and bust cycle of economics. If a predator overhunts its prey, the prey population will lower to numbers that are too scarce for the predators to find. This will cause the predator population to dip, decreasing the predation pressure on the prey population. The decrease in predators will allow the small number of prey left to slowly increase their population to somewhere around their previous abundance, which will allow the predator population to increase in response to the greater availability of resources. The other usage refers to a language that is socially subordinated to a regional or national standard language, often historically cognate or related to the standard language, but not actually derived from it. In this sense, unlike in the first usage, the standard language would not itself be considered a "dialect," as it is the dominant language in a particular state or region, whether in terms of social or political status, official status, predominance or prevalence, or all of the above. Meanwhile, the "dialects" subordinate to the standard language are generally not variations on the standard language but rather separate (but often related) languages in and of themselves. For example, most of the various regional Romance languages of Italy, often colloquially referred to as Italian "dialects," are, in fact, not actually derived from modern standard Italian, but rather evolved from Vulgar Latin separately and individually from one another and independently of standard Italian, long prior to the diffusion of a national standardized language throughout what

The northwestern portion of Rajasthan is generally sandy and dry. Most of this region are covered by the Thar Desert which extends into adjoining portions of Pakistan. The Aravalli Range does not intercept the moisture-giving southwest monsoon winds off the Arabian Sea, as it lies in a direction parallel to that of the coming monsoon winds, leaving the northwestern region in a rain shadow. The Thar Desert is thinly populated; the town of Jodhpur is the largest city in the desert and known as the gateway of thar desert. The desert has some major districts like Jodhpur, Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner and Nagour. This area is also important defence point of view. Jodhpur airbase is Indias largest airbase and military, BSF bases are also situated here. A single civil airport is also situated in Jodhpur. The Northwestern thorn scrub forests lie in a band around the Thar Desert, between the desert and the Aravallis. This region receives less than 400 mm of rain in an average year. In the United States, Lindlof and Taylor write, "Cultural studies [were] grounded in a pragmatic, liberal-pluralist tradition". The American version of cultural studies initially concerned itself more with understanding the subjective and appropriative side of audience reactions to, and uses of, mass culture; for example, American cultural-studies advocates wrote about the liberatory aspects of fandom.[citation needed] The distinction between American and British strands, however, has faded.[citation needed] Some researchers, especially in early British cultural studies, apply a Marxist model to the field. This strain of thinking has some influence from the Frankfurt School, but especially from the structuralist Marxism of Louis Althusser and others. The main focus of an orthodox Marxist approach concentrates on the production of meaning. Economists Hendrik Wolff, Howard Chong and Maximilian Auffhammer discuss the HDI from the perspective of data error in the underlying health, education and income statistics used to construct the HDI. They identified three sources of data error which are due to (i) data updating, (ii) formula revisions and (iii) thresholds to classify a country’s development status and conclude that 11%, 21% and 34% of all countries can be interpreted as currently misclassified in the development bins due to the three sources of data error, respectively. The authors suggest that the United Nations should discontinue the practice of classifying countries into development bins because - they claim - the cut-off values seem arbitrary, can provide incentives for strategic behavior in reporting official statistics, and have the potential to misguide politicians, investors, charity donors and the public who use the HDI at large.[citation needed] In 2010 the UNDP reacted to the criticism and updated the thresholds to classify nations as low, medium, and

The KU men's basketball team has fielded a team every year since 1898. The Jayhawks are a perennial national contender currently coached by Bill Self. The team has won five national titles, including three NCAA tournament championships in 1952, 1988, and 2008. The basketball program is currently the second winningest program in college basketball history with an overall record of 2,070–806 through the 2011–12 season. The team plays at Allen Fieldhouse. The manuscript according to Zayd remained with Abu Bakr until he died. Zayd's reaction to the task and the difficulties in collecting the Quranic material from parchments, palm-leaf stalks, thin stones and from men who knew it by heart is recorded in earlier narratives. The morning after the election, the major candidates were neck and neck. It was clear that the result in Ohio, along with two other states who had still not declared (New Mexico and Iowa), would decide the winner. Bush had established a lead of around 130,000 votes but the Democrats pointed to provisional ballots that had yet to be counted, initially reported to number as high as 200,000. Bush had preliminary leads of less than 5% of the vote in only four states, but if Iowa, Nevada and New Mexico had all eventually gone to Kerry, a win for Bush in Ohio would have created a 269–269 tie in the Electoral College. The result of an electoral tie would cause the election to be decided in the House of Representatives with each state casting one vote, regardless of population. Nanjing ( listen; Chinese: 南京, "Southern Capital") is the city situated in the heartland of lower Yangtze River region in China, which has long been a major centre of culture, education, research, politics, economy, transport networks and tourism. It is the capital city of Jiangsu province of People's Republic of China and the second largest city in East China, with a total population of 8,216,100, and legally the capital of Republic of China which lost the mainland during the civil war. The city whose name means "Southern Capital" has a prominent place in Chinese history and culture, having served as the capitals of various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms and republican governments dating from the 3rd century AD to 1949. Other historians find incongruity in the proposition that the very place where the vast number of the scholars that influenced the scientific revolution received their education should also be the place that inhibits their research and the advancement of science. In fact, more than 80% of the European scientists between 1450–1650 included in the Dictionary of Scientific Biography were university trained, of which approximately 45% held university posts. It was the case that the academic foundations remaining from the Middle Ages were stable, and they did provide for an environment that fostered considerable growth and development. There was considerable reluctance on the part of universities to relinquish the symmetry and comprehensiveness provided by the Aristotelian system, which was effective as a coherent system for understanding and interpreting the world. However, university professors still utilized some autonomy, at least in the sciences, to choose epistemological foundations and methods. Israel has a school life expectancy of 15.5 years and a literacy rate of 97.1% according to the United Nations. The State Education Law, passed in 1953, established five types of schools: state secular, state religious, ultra orthodox, communal settlement schools, and Arab schools. The public secular is the largest school group, and is attended by the majority of Jewish and non-Arab pupils in Israel. Most Arabs send their children to schools where Arabic is the language of instruction. Education is compulsory in Israel for children between the ages of three and eighteen. Schooling is divided into three tiers – primary school (grades 1–6), middle school (grades 7–9), and high school (grades 10–12) – culminating with Bagrut matriculation exams. Proficiency in core subjects such as mathematics, the Hebrew language, Hebrew and general literature, the English language, history, Biblical scripture and civics is necessary to receive a Bagrut certificate. An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that adolescents from poor, minority, and racial background are missing out on opportunities to develop their identity due to their environments. In this paper, I take adolescents from the East End of Kingston, Jamaica to the city of Atlanta, Georgia to explore their lived experience of their identity through a series of observations. A new study method using a semi-structured research interview was utilized to explore the adolescent's daily activities such as school, neighborhood, and social interactions. The results of the study reveal the social, emotional, and academic disadvantages that adolescents from low wealth and low socio-economic background (SES) experience due to poverty and structural racism.

It wasn't just the UK. A decade after the fall of communism, the royal family became a new target for sensational headlines, many of them based on tabloid journalism.

"We lived through a very tumultuous decade," says Tim Soutphommasane, executive director at the Guardian Media Institute in Britain. "After communism, lots of countries had issues with the family, and particularly with the queen. So much of royal reporting was political in the sense that you're trying to undermine the monarchy."

And tabloid writers were more than happy to oblige.

From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, Martin Lee and Anthony DeMille, laid the foundations for all the work done by sociologists and social scientists in the following decades.

Hall became Professor of Sociology in 1970 at the School of Social Science at Warwick University, remaining at this level until 1972. He was made Professor Emeritus by the end of 1999, and he retired in 2000. Since then he has worked in a number of teaching posthumously, mainly specialising in issues and controversies in public affairs. His work covers the fields of political and policy studies, cultural studies, government and politics, economic sociology, social action, political economy, management, social psychology, educational studies, policy sociology, social change, and political systems. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism level. Furthermore, the patterns of different colored pelage within a population can vary in color, texture and/or size among individuals within that population. Many different morphotypes may exist within a species, and may thus differ in pelage color and size. Differences in pelage color may be due to genetic or environmental change including the presence of predators, parasites or other factors that affect pelage, especially in a population that has a wide range of morphotypes. This genetic variation and other environmental influences can also cause changes in appearance in individuals in non-pelagic environments, such as the ocean.

Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology, particularly with the stress systems. This is important because emotions are, in essence, part of the basic metabolic functions of the nervous system. They impact the immune system, brain and other systems that impact behavior and relationships. When emotions are triggered, the nervous system starts releasing the corresponding hormones and neurotransmitters. That will trigger both the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems at the same time, meaning the emotional state is being interpreted in multiple systems. The hormonal state of being triggered in multiple systems means that many behaviors - from the cardiovascular system to the respiratory system - may differ depending on the person's level of stress and the physiological state.

Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles give a long critique of the application of FST to human populations in their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and Human Evolution: The FST Paradox" and in response they provide two criticisms of FST. While long, FST does not get the attention that it deserves and this article provides an extensive critique of the shortcomings of their criticism. The criticism by Long and Kittles (2003) may be a good starting point for those interested in re-evaluating their theory. To provide a more detailed analysis, below, we will examine some of the strengths of their criticism and attempt to demonstrate that they could not construct an alternative theory that is as robust to the empirical evidence as the original FST. Israelites enjoyed political independence twice in ancient history, first during the periods of the Biblical judges followed by the United Monarchy.[disputed – discuss] This time period came to an end with the Bar Kokhba revolt of 132 BC. Israel’s political independence remained shaky until the Roman occupation of the land in the 1st century BC.

By the 1st century AD the Roman Empire (Latin Empire, as it was also called) was the dominant power in the area at large and Judea (the ancient name of the region) was incorporated into the empire as a province. The Roman Empire expanded east in pursuit of a new frontier, the Hellenistic frontier along the Mediterranean, which was a key geopolitical imperative of the empire. The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, and in the south are the Alps, which form a vast escarpment through Thuringia. In the east and the west of Thuringia rise the mountains of the Neckar valley, while in the south they lie in the vicinity of the River Isar.
In the west, the Eifel mountains stretch from here to the Rhine and make their boundary with the west. The Odenwald lies eastward, while all the surrounding hills have either the name “Thuringian” or “Lippe” on them (e.g. Harz, Saale, Elbe). Thuringia is crossed by rivers—the Saale, the Main, the Thuringische Elbe and the Schwedt.

On 6 May 1437, at the Battle of Agincourt, Louis’ army defeated the English at their strategic location for that day, Agincourt near Amiens. Louis did not make many victories against other English kings, but when he did, it was an insurmountable advantage.

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangea began to disintegrate and a number of islands erupted to become the continents of Laurasia and Gondwana. Gondwana was then formed out of this debris; some of the pieces are now known as North America, Australia, South America, and Eurasia, while the rest remain in place. During the mid-Jurassic Period (202.8 to 165.7 Ma), a major land mass broke away, and most of the continents lost their crustal crust. These events are the origin of continental drift (the separation of the earth into different continents, which change their relative positions in time and space). This was the first major break-up of a single continental plate.

The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, a tribe who arrived in the area between 3000 and 2900 BCE.

One of the oldest rock art sites in Europe is found in Galicia in Spain. Its date is uncertain, but it is likely to be some 200,000 years ago. These rocks are known as the 'Strait Stones' as they are the only complete series of these that has been found to date.

The site was discovered in 1933 by the Italian archaeologist, Luigi Guidi.

Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals do. Also, oxygen diffusion can take place over large areas under the skin, so long as the bird has a significant surface area to volume.
Ahh, okay, so since it's smaller, there's a higher surface area to blood exchange rate?
Yeah, but also because they're smaller you'll have more surface area of skin exposed to anaerobic environment and you'll have more of the blood being circulated up against the inner walls of the lungs. Just a few things going in favor of birds to be more efficient.  That said, I'm not sure about avian physiology but I would imagine the whole point of feathers is to reduce aerodynamic drag, which is probably a contributing factor to the high oxygen diffusion in birds.

Hong Taiji's bureaucracy was staffed with many Han Chinese, including many newly surrendered Ming officials. During the Ming/Qing wars, the Manchus generally fought against the Qing but never invaded China.

In contemporary society, adolescents also face some risks as their sexuality begins to transform. While some of these, such as emotional distress (fear of intimacy) and substance abuse, are common risk factors, others, such as sexual violence, are more complex and vary in depth across populations. The prevalence of these types of risk is dependent not only on adolescent demographics, but also on their sexual practices, attitudes about sex, and risk perceptions. It is common for adults to believe that adolescents don't experience any risk factors for these problems. However, in our society, there is often a great lack of understanding about adolescents as adults. This makes the prevention of sexual violence among adolescents a difficult issue that must be addressed in order for adolescents' sexual rights to be respected and for them to be safe. A government report covered by the Guardian in 2002 indicates that between 1940 and 1979, the Ministry of Defence "turned large parts of the country into a battlefield". The report states: "In wartime, the Ministry of Defense has not always been constrained by the constraints of time, place or political ideology. The history of Ministry of defence action shows its long-standing tendency to ignore local political requirements and to act with little regard for the welfare of the people on the ground, as well as towards the international community."

A similar situation has been described by the UK's Conflict Studies Group, as part of a report entitled "The War on Terror in Iraq and Afghanistan: Political and Tactical Analysis".

The report notes: "Unlike the Ministry of Defence (MOD), other branches of government and their agencies have generally been restrained in the use of force that the MOD has engaged in. The MOD has engaged in acts of aggression that are likely to have resulted in the deaths of thousands of civilians."

The Guangxu Emperor died on November 14, 1908, and on November 15, 1908, Cixi also died. Rumors held that their lives were connected by the curse of ghosts.

In his short life, the emperor suffered five miscarriages of pregnancy and a great deal of labor pain in childbirth, and he never bore a child. Cixi was born nine months after his brother’s death in 1905, and he was named after his father, Guan, which means "courage," according to a biography by the British Museum. Cixi's personality was described as "stubborn and stubborn…she was prone to get irritated by anyone trying to talk to her."

Like many emperors across China who died in the 1,100-year history of the Qing Dynasty, Cixi’s remains were interred in the Forbidden City; it was not until 1924 that his body was moved outside for public viewing.

Public priests were appointed by the collegia. Once elected, a priest held permanent religious authority from the eternal divine, which offered him lifetime influence, status, wealth, or power. With the introduction of papal elections, both temporal and spiritual power over the church was vested in one person, the pope itself, who has the authority to choose his own successor.

In a very short period of time, the popes became the ultimate authority – they were not simply the spiritual successors of their predecessors but the actual founder of the Christian Church in all of its diversity. They claimed to have been raised from the dead, and thus they claimed to have divine power over men. As the papacy spread across Europe, the idea that any pope was divine spread as well, in the form of the notion of Papism. The term Papism was developed when the Church recognized that the successor to St Peter was not merely a religious but also a temporal prince – a claim that was made on both sides

Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, participants "ladder" up through the number of times they have won. The numbers of wins are referred to as "ladders", and each ladder represents a victory.

The process is a bit unconventional. Two participants "ladder" in a "lackadaisical fashion", with each ladder representing one victory. This results in the number of wins for participants climbing the ladder (ladders) and the number of wins for participants descending the ladder being equal, resulting in a winner.

Although ladder matches make it hard to predict outcomes, they are popular with the fans and have become the de facto standard format for "special" matches.

The modern definition of ladder matches can be expressed in two ways. The first is to ask whether one ladder or set of ladders forms the basis on which a match is constructed.

A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, the true predator can be able to kill its prey by pure instinct. Predators only need to consume their prey to survive, the hunting instinct is completely separate to the instinctive ability to eat. Predators without any hunting ability need to gain their hunting ability through experience.

The true predator usually needs to live off land, as predators are highly adapted to live off of land and animals, although not all true predators live entirely by living off of land. A good example of this is some dinosaurs that lived on land, although their ancestors were in water. The true predator also may use hunting methods that aren’t always obvious because predators are usually very good at hiding their presence from other predators.

The true predator is the one that causes the most harm to its prey, since true predators are typically the ones that have evolved the greatest adaptations

The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed on February 2, 1848, by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary Miguel Hidalgo, was the final piece of a bargain drawn up in 1848 between the United States, Mexico's former colonial foe, and the Mexican Revolutionaries that had overthrew Mexican Emperor Maximilian in 1821 and proclaimed the republic of Mexico in 1824 as part of the Mexican War of Independence. It was one of the last major foreign policy decisions taken by President Harrison's administration, and it created the relationship between Mexico and the United States into what it is today. This blog explores the history and diplomatic events that led up to it, providing an interesting historical perspective on what has become the largest bilateral and multinational alliance in the world today.

From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles, and show how all of physics would unfold.

So he could "think" about the universe from the point of view of any tiny, subatomic particle.

In fact, there are physicists out there right now who claim to be able to think with the smallest particles.

The so-called Higgs boson is the Higgs particle - or rather the particle of masses which gives mass to everything else - and many physicists feel it can solve a mysterious problem in quantum mechanics, which refers to the behavior of subatomic particles at very tiny scales.

Particles with masses can not only spin in different directions, but they can also interact and behave entirely differently.

For example, particles of iron can change their spins in opposite ways depending on their size.

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept, one's sense of one's ability to cope with various personal and emotional challenges and needs, and the degree to which one believes one has the capacity to overcome problems and acquire appropriate levels of happiness and fulfillment. The two main determinants of self-esteem are self-knowledge and personal-knowledge. Self-knowledge refers principally to ones own abilities and strengths both real and perceived and ones own limitations. Self-knowledge is necessary for assessing the effects that one has on other people given the potential for self-transcendence and thus is necessary for setting goals, pursuing personal values and fulfilling one's dreams. Personal-knowledge refers to someone's knowledge of one's own self-concept and ability to cope with stress. In April 1864, a number of schools were organized in Gallatin County. The purpose of the schools was to teach the children of the pioneers, who had traveled westward with the Oregon Trail. The county's schools were consolidated to form the Gallatin County School system in 1872. The county is the largest of Montana's three judicial districts.

Several explanations have been offered for Yale’s representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism in the 1980s and 90s, when protest organizing, student strike actions, and student-led civil disobedience transformed a sense of what college would be like for thousands of young Americans. Some note the student protests and strikes for immigration reform and against the war in Iraq. Others point to the election success of the late Yale president Lee Bollinger. But my theory is that Yale’s representation in national elections reflects a changing role for America’s oldest university in the national politics of the United States. While the U.S. population may have grown substantially over the past fifty years, Yale has remained relatively stable politically. Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of Britain’s industrial capacity had been destroyed, a huge proportion of industry and industry infrastructure had been destroyed on the Continent, and the postwar world was greatly damaged. By far the largest military action in which the United States engaged during this era was the War of 1812. With Britain locked in a major war against France, and little real appetite for such a struggle, the war itself was something of a surprise to the American public. The conflict had almost no direct American causalities, and yet it cost nearly $100 million in today’s dollars (a figure which rose to more than $600 million in 1818).

The War of 1812 is notable for its unique role in the political evolution of the United States, and especially for the emergence of American nationalism. That, more than any other historical phenomenon, is what is unique about the American Revolution. For that reason, I find it fascinating that the War of 1812 is not treated as a part of American history as a whole, even though it has much in common, even the same basic result, as the Revolutionary War!

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very different from those involved in the storage and retrieval of recorded information in the brain. To understand the difference, we must first understand how the brain stores and retrieves information. The structure and functional activity of neurons and brain regions that are involved in the storage and retrieval of information reflect both the brain's processes and the underlying molecular circuits. Using the methods of functional neuroimaging, cell biology and computational modeling, we will illustrate the critical differences between these two modes of memory storage and, thus, the limitations of recording techniques when used to study these processes.

Neuroscience graduate student Matthew J. Stearns will serve as a research assistant for this lecture. Graduate student Andrew Kostelnik will also perform experiments in the lab.

A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g. “anger” or “frustration”). According to one hypothesis there are two distinct kinds of emotions which have been argued to be core to the experience of society: emotional labor vs. non-emotional labor, and affective work vs. apolitical or intellectual work. We consider this distinction a useful one in terms of making meaning of social media and digital interactions.

‘The digital is emotional, but not emotional in the same way’: How emotions and technology intersect for the digital.

While emotions have always been present on the internet, there were earlier technologies such as the telephone in which users would sometimes experience positive emotions as well. However, as more people became acquainted with technology the internet developed more quickly, and today it is increasingly the medium through which the majority of people express their emotions.

Darwin was hard at work on his "big book" on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, on behalf of the Naturalist's Society in Edinburgh. Darwin soon set about making his ideas on the subject of the inheritance of traits through natural selection fully known and put forward to the then science community. He published the first edition in 1867.

Darwin's 1859 The Origin of Species attracted little interest. The first edition of The Descent of Man (1871) was welcomed enthusiastically, however, and the publication of this also gave a much-needed boost to botany and the "science of the tree". Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology; astrolatry and astrometry were prominent themes in medieval philosophy), and ethics and religious studies.

By 1350, however, universities had been organized in the various areas of natural philosophy, logic, medicine, law, art, mathematics, philosophy, logic, logic and theology, etc., and the liberal arts had merged with the sciences and with classical culture. University pedagogy emphasized the use of "science" to study human nature or even the "natural world" as it was understood. Humanistic concerns flourished, not necessarily in relation to theology, but with the search for knowledge and for human flourishing or happiness. Later universities combined some of the scientific skills of ancient times with a more humanist concern with how these skills could be applied to the problems of everyday life. The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to create policy and budgets. A board-only organization elects the board and makes policy decisions.

Member nonprofits that are not eligible for Section 501(c) (3) nonprofit status generally cannot provide gifts or payments to other nonprofit organizations; however, they can form a cooperative with a Section 501(c) (3) organization and do other business dealings. If a member nonprofit wishes to contribute to a Section 501(c)(3) nonprofit without any restrictions, it must report the total in its annual report for IRS tax purposes. However, Section 501(c)(3) nonprofits generally do not need to report their individual contributions.

A nonprofit may receive gifts and payments from an affiliate. Such gifts and payments are generally income to the nonprofit from the affiliate. Gifts and payments that exceed 20% of the nonprofit’s annual revenue

Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. Depending on the allegations, the accused member may be forbidden from all church membership practices until the elders determine his or her situation. The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "civil wars", in fact their causes were complex and varied. In France, the collapse of the western Roman Empire, as well as other events, were the causes for the foundation of the Ancien Régime in the north of the country. In Spain, the end of the late Roman empire in the formative period gave the Spanish kings political control over the empire at the expense of political power, which began to be increasingly exercised over the cities of northern Spain.

The formation of the Spanish crown was made possible by the establishment of a new constitution by the Spanish king in a set of rules known as the Ancien Régime. The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern (primarily Spain, Italy and Portugal) universities are not so different.

In western Europe, the university is very much a public institution with the government owning the property and the university board taking operational decisions. In northern Europe, the university is not quite so public and universities are largely funded by the academic salaries of those who work there. This means that a large chunk of the budget goes to a central administration—the university president—or is dispersed through autonomous boards.

Academic freedom is very important in the northern university. It is based on the principle of free discussion—you are free to pursue your own research and publish it, even though it would not be popular with the committee of one professor working on a PhD. This also allows freedom to take decisions: the president can take a decision even if the whole committee says no

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. The growth medium is then exposed to or contacted with the specific agent in a liquid medium called culture broth. The culture is then monitored to see whether the agent in the culture has reproduced in it. In order to provide reliable diagnosis of infectious disease, the agents or microbes in the culture must be cultured in the same conditions, environment, or media that are routinely encountered by the infected person. A typical example is a culture of the bacterium staphylococcus aureus.
The standard culture media used in biological cultures include carbon dioxide and buffer, which is the balance between oxygen and hydrocarbon as the only active compounds. Culture media comprise a carbohydrate known as maltose, an amine in the form of aminopyridine (e.g., aqueous alkanolamine), vitamins such as riboflavin and others.

The current Mac product family uses Intel x86-64 processors. Apple introduced an emulator during the transition from PowerPC chips (called Rosetta), which allowed for applications written for them to run on Intel x86 processors. However, the emulation was abandoned during the transition to Intel CPUs, and Rosetta2 was discontinued in the mid-2000s, meaning applications still using Rosetta2-based code must be ported to run directly on Intel processors, which is a long process, and may not even be possible.

The transition to Apple's own ARM processors that replace Intel processors is ongoing and is expected to be finalized by the end of 2020 (in part due to the limitations of older Mac OS X software, which cannot directly access RAM). By then, the latest Macs, including any future Mac Mini and Mac minis, should be available, and this may change how ARM applications were developed, for the best or worse, but it won't affect how OS X applications are built

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much knowledge. They are essentially powerless. Adolescence and puberty, however, is a time of dramatic growth and development. Young boys develop a sense of social responsibility, desire, ambition and assertiveness. Young girls may begin to question traditional roles, such as family and church. They tend to rely more on peer influence. To facilitate this transition, and to give parents and young people information on how they might best communicate with and help support their children, the Adolescent Resource Line of the Children's Ministry of the First Presbyterian Church in Fort Pierce presents Teen Confessions. The column invites teens who live, work, study or worship in the city to share their experiences during the teenage years, with special consideration given to subjects of faith, life and sexuality.

Teen Confessions takes place every other Sunday at 2 p.m. in the Gathering Place

Marshalls operated in the Minneapolis-St. Paul market until closing its last shop in 2003. Marshall Field's has since been rebranded as Macy's.

In 2011, Macy's acquired The Limited and their assets, and The Limited's website was subsequently merged with Macy's.

Homer refers to the "Hellenes" (/ˈhɛliːnz/) as a relatively small tribe settled in Thessalonica that he mentions first in the 13th century BC, but was most probably also mentioned by other Greek sources, such as Hesiod in the 12th century BC. According to Homer, the Hellenes were a very small tribe living far in the south of Greece, which became even more pronounced as time passed. This tribe, in Homer's own estimation, was a people, though one that spoke a somewhat different language. He also refers to the Hellenes as a people, although this may refer to a specific small settlement, since he would not have been describing the entire village. According to Homer, the Hellenes lived at a place called Sarpedona and had a "wild man" (pāllinē) who was "more numerous in number than the rest".

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which began in the 16th century. The scientific debate began in earnest with the publication of Erasmus (1595), a 15-year-old Italian boy who asked his father for books of history. His father sent him a copy of William Camden's The History of Creation, written more than a century earlier. Erasmus' book was important because it introduced the term "race" to Western Europe. Erasmus' idea was that "race" had an evolutionary origin, and that races are a feature of the physical and cultural diversity that is part of society. The idea of race has been with all humans from the beginning of our species on Earth, and its appearance in Europe coincides with the appearance of ancient civilizations, such as the ancient Egyptians, Greeks, Romans, and the Middle Ages and Renaissance. The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US). While the space race is generally associated with the US, the effort to put man into space had far-reaching impact across many countries, influencing technological development and the political agenda of many. This exhibition will look at the history, politics and geopolitics of the space race and the subsequent history of space exploration and exploration planning.
Spaceflight was a revolutionary concept at the time, allowing the world’s first man on the moon, the first to travel in space across the globe, space tourism and ultimately to the International Space Station. With more of a focus on the Cold War rivalry behind it, a narrative tends to highlight the events and missions focused on the Space Race. However, this exhibition aims to understand the far-reaching impact of the race from many different angles.

In surveys made in Europe and the United States, green is the color most commonly associated with nature, life, health, youth, spring, hope, peace and happiness. Yet in the real world, this popular color is anything but. It is associated with death, decay, pollution, decay and despair. In fact, according to polls compiled in the early 1970s, as many as 85 percent of Americans considered green the color of decay—deadliness—while only 8 percent viewed it as life and 15 percent viewed it as spring.

The environmental health movement has also seen its share of greenwash, with such groups as the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or the National Resources Defense Council (NRDC) claiming that the “environment” is healthy when, in fact, environmental health—the condition of plants and animals in the natural world—is compromised in the name of health.

After Cassander's death in 298 BCE, however, Demetrius, who still maintained a sizable loyal army and fleet, invaded Macedon, and the empire was effectively ended. The Romans did not manage to rebuild it after that, and Greece has since been the seat of the Ionian League, composed of several island republics.

Demetrius's military campaign had serious consequences for the Romans in Greece during the early phase of the third century BCE. After Demetrius invaded Macedon, they were forced to acknowledge the existence of the Ionian League. Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period, plenty of sunshine, and a moderate rainfall, usually from 600 to 1,200 millimetres.[3] If the ideal moisture level is achieved[4] cotton plants develop at an average rate of about 1.9 millimetres per day in a normal growing season. As the temperature warms cotton flowers.[5] From the end of February until mid-March, temperatures can rise over 35 °C (95 °F). This rapid growth causes cotton to swell up to double its normal size, giving it more area, and consequently more weight. As the plants bloom and ripen, the flowers begin to wither and drop off. They release their energy to the seeds making them ripe for the picking. Once the plant has finished growth they stop releasing seed and start making new, smaller seeds.[6]

There are several types of cotton available today. Cotton fibre comes in varying levels of softness and fineness

In October 2014, the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began. All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office by failing to report on issues of child abuse in the church. Intel had tried unsuccessfully to push Apple to migrate the Macintosh platform to Intel chips. Apple concluded that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) processors had problems with the graphics hardware provided on its own PowerPC chips. Apple wanted an independent graphics processor and a new type of memory to be used by its systems, but Intel refused.

Apple finally abandoned Intel altogether in 1995 and began making the PowerPC system chips in its own facilities.[29][30] Apple and Intel continued to be competitors; Intel's processors continued to appear in products from other computer manufacturers, including those that sold under the Mac name. Apple continued to ship its own products with Intel processors, although its support for Intel began to ease beginning in 1996. As Intel's processor sales declined, it also fell out of favor with Apple.[11][12]

Jefferson and James Madison's conceptions of separation have long been debated. Jefferson refused to issue Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress because he would have to "begrudge the prayers to God which [Congress] had been forced to make as an acknowledgment of the indebtedness of this country for that prosperity." When Congress passed the Bill of Rights he said it should become law. Madison declared that he "had always conceived separation... [was] the only basis of freedom." And when Congress passed the Bank Amendment on March 28, 1833, Madison said, "I believe the amendment is constitutional, and that it will have constitutional value; and I rejoice that the government seems again to have taken the road which I believe is at last right and wise." As for how Congress ought to separate from the people, Madison suggested they "give and take," which he thought was a better idea than "separation and annexation." Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a position that excludes the other party. An inclusive boundary does not, hence, exclude. I am a Christian, says one person, but I do also believe in evolution and do not necessarily oppose gay marriage. This person’s inclusive boundaries would embrace the Christian part without excluding the evolution part. On the other hand, a closed exclusive boundary would include the evolution part but not embrace the Christian part.

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different diets led to the evolution of other different types of mammals. Mammals may have lived much longer, had smaller brains or different body sizes, but the overall traits for living a long and happy life remained the same.

There wasn’t just one “perfect” way to feed ourselves. Instead, different environments gave different mammals their best options. Here’s where we get the idea that all mammals eat the same food and all mammals have a wide variety of diets. But mammals only get a wide variety of diets as a result of environmental interactions.

To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This means in that the section of line downstream of its feeder station should be isolated from other sections of line downstream where possible. As a result, a special disconnect fitting must be provided on each line or disconnect fitting must be connected to line with its own break away section. This means that the line should be separated in such a way that a disconnect fitting is required upstream of a particular section, line, or section of line.
One way of solving this problem is the addition of a further break away section of the existing line and then connecting it both to an outside break away section as well as to a section of line downstream from it. However, this requires additional connecting sections and can be time consuming and awkward to connect. Asian Americans in New York City, according to the 2010 Census, number more than one million, greater than the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles and equal to the population of New Jersey. There are about 840,000 Asian American households with children in the city, an increase of over 70 percent since 1980. Asian Americans represent the second largest immigrant ethnic group in NYC after Latinos and the fifth largest immigrant population overall. In the NYC area, one in four of every Asian and Pacific Islander residents is now Hispanic, up from 1 in 4 for the entire US in 1990. The Asian American population now accounts for 7 of every 10 US non-Hispanic Asian Americans.

The Han had long grown tired of their imperial and ruling rulers who would dress at public ceremonies in short, bushy beards and moustaches while their own personal beards, moustaches, and hair were kept long. Dorgon's order led to a wave of Han Chinese beards and moustaches. By 1572, Han Chinese had more of every kind of beard and moustache than any other people in North or South America, Africa, Southeast Asia, Europe, the Arab World, Southeast Asia, and North Africa in the entire world.

The relationships adolescents have with their peers, family, and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent. As young people age and move into adolescent development, factors such as the transition, the role reversal, the emergence into sexual maturity, and the process of change in the body and in one’s emotional and spiritual development all have a part in defining the peer relationships an adolescent encounters. This chapter uses an adolescent point of view to look at some of the challenges peers and adolescents experience in establishing and maintaining peer relationships. Although adolescent peer relationships often are viewed as problematic situations and as a cause of behavioral problems, the adolescent is able to successfully navigate social interaction and relationships in all types of settings (Sampson et al., 2000). Furthermore, the literature that has been written on young adult peer relationships indicates that early peer relationships may be the most formative for young adults’ social and emotional development (Goddard and Nivart, 1999).

One group in particular: workers of Walthamstow.

At first the bomb shelter, which had been used for many years by the Communists before the Blitz, proved inadequate: it was too small, and people had to cross a field to get to it. And so in 1938, the Communist group built a bigger, more accessible shelter, which stood in the park near the old railway line that ran from Walthamstow to Poplar, near where the workers' community was situated. The new shelter was built by a group of labourers who worked at an asbestos factory in the town of Stoke Newington, north-west of London.

Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, President Harry S. Truman, himself a combat veteran of World War I, issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the Medal of Honor.

The Medal of Honor was awarded to Woodard for his heroism in defending a position against the Japanese at Iwo Jima during World War II, where he was wounded and captured while on a mountain pass. He was honored for his valor on December 19, 1945, at the age of 46.

The last Marine to receive the Medal of Honor was Staff Sgt. Charles H. Protestants also took the initiative in advocating for religious freedom. Freedom of conscience had high priority on the theological, philosophical, and political agendas since the early days of the Protestant Reformation. This trend continued to the present. This is an issue that is being tackled today by religious leaders in the United States, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, Germany, the United Kingdom, Norway and Switzerland.

What Is Religious Freedom?

Religious freedom is the freedom to practice one’s religious beliefs without persecution or adverse social repercussions. The government recognizes its obligation not to restrict or punish a person for the spiritual practices that person engages in, or permit the establishment of a regime that regulates these practices.

Australia’s freedom to practice religious faith, the freedoms of the citizen to speak, write or act and the freedom of religion are based on the notion that individuals ought not to be compelled to make their choices on matters that are central to their identity.

On December 13, 2013, Beyoncé unexpectedly released her eponymous fifth studio album on the iTunes Store without any prior announcement or promotion. The album debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200, earned the best first-week sales total for a female singer since Taylor Swift’s Reputation (2017) and broke several other records. The album’s sales also set a record for the best weekly sales in US history for an album by a solo artist, with over 603,000 units (equivalent to 894,000,000 in 2012). It is the third best-selling album of 2013, and is certified 7x platinum (7 million sold in the US) by the Recording Industry Association of America.

In the process, the album became the best selling album of 2013 in both the United States and the United Kingdom, the first album to surpass Taylor Swift’s 1989 (2011) sales since Michael Jackson’s Thriller (1982).

Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of fevers, urinary infections, or fevers from exposure to contaminated water came from indigenous plants, animals, and minerals. The first successful drug developed after 1804 was quinine. Since 19th century, the field of pharmacognosy has described herbal materials for use in treatment of infection and diseases. More recently, this field has been developed into a multidisciplinary research area encompassing the study of herbal medicines in a global context.
The field is generally divided into three sections: ethnobotany (the use of natural substances by people and their culture, generally as a religious or ritual activity), medicinal ecology (the study of the interactions of people and plants), and modern pharmacognosy or pharmacology (the study of natural extracts from plants and how they influence biological actions of drugs). A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not reset between the halves. This standard adult football game takes place in a rectangular stadium with a pitch that is 2 metres by 1 metre, and no goal posts.

The football players in a normal adult football match start out standing, with players from both sides making a circle around the ball. The goal keeper takes the ball into this centre, as did the keeper in a modern children’s football game. The centre player then passes the ball back to the other teams centre, who now takes it behind the goalposts. The players then stand up and move into a team position for the second half of the football game. The opposing teams make another circle around the ball, starting near the centre of the pitch, and moving behind the goalposts. Regardless, the Luftwaffe could still inflict huge damage. With the German occupation of Western Europe, the intensification of submarine and air attack, and the use of incendiary bombs on British cities, London itself was considered to be too dangerous for the city population to remain. It was necessary for the city's evacuation.

With the city in the hands of British troops, the Luftwaffe launched attacks that destroyed the London Underground. The underground continued to be used but it had become a death trap for civilians.

The Luftwaffe also destroyed the London Power Station as it had become a focus for Allied air and naval forces. The only significant survivor of the original power station was the concrete dome remaining over the centre ground.

The Luftwaffe's destruction of the power station left the UK with only one working nuclear power station (the MoD) and no coal or oil power stations.

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to practice, evaluate, and reinforce social skills and group attitudes, especially in the context of adolescence. Understanding the developmental and structural reasons for adolescent peer group behavior can be important for developing effective counseling approaches that promote peer group functioning and well-being in adolescence.

Theoretically, adolescents are naturally drawn to social and peer groups for positive purposes. Some of the reasons peers form groups are related to personality; some of the reasons peer groups exist are related to group membership. Group formation by adolescents may occur in one of two settings, either natural or created. Peers create group relationships when they organize to attend to group goals. Group formation in natural settings, however, occurs whenever two or more people of a similar age form an informal group, such as in a school or community group. Peer groups form spontaneously during the transition phase from adolescence to adulthood

In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite some initial resistance, within a decade Philadelphia became Pennsylvania’s major port of arrival to the New World and the first major commercial center in the New World. (It was this center that gave the world the word “syndicate,” which would later come to mean a group of people with equal shares of common property or profits.)

Pennsylvania’s unique identity has given it a complex history. During its early years, British colonial settlers moved into Pennsylvania, followed by a host of various types of indigenous peoples from around the world, the Dutch, Huguenots and the Spaniards.
